title: Investigation of Alumina Atomic-Scale Structure and Crystallization Behavior Across a β-Ga2O3/Al2O3 Interface
content: Interfaces can induce unique material behavior due to strain, electronic band bending, and their potential stabilization of defects. Several prior studies have observed crystallization behavior within the alumina (Al2O3) system, especially when grown on beta gallium oxide (β-Ga2O3) [1-3]. β-Ga2O3 is a promising next generation ultrawide band gap semiconductor, possessing a band gap of 4.8 eV and a tunable carrier concentration via an array of doping candidates [4]. In an amorphous form, Al2O3 has been extensively studied as an insulator in the semiconductor industry and specifically as a gate dielectric in β-Ga2O3 devices [5-7]. Understanding Al2O3/β-Ga2O3 heterointerfaces is vital for developing versatile β-Ga2O3 device applications, since Al2O3’s relation to β-Ga2O3 across an interface is of broad interest in the power electronics industry. The most stable alumina crystalline polymorph, α-Al2O3, is a well understood crystal with the corundum structure (R-3c point group). The exact atomic structures of the other Al2O3 polymorphs, however, are not as well understood [8-10]. Monoclinic θ-Al2O3 has primarily been studied for applications in catalysis and was recently proposed to be a mixture of β-Ga2O3-like monoclinic regions interspersed by perpendicular columns of octahedral Al atoms, creating a monoclinic structure not fully analogous to β-Ga2O3 [11]. In this study, we present some of the first examples of θ-Al2O3 stabilization across a β-Ga2O3 interface. Our prior studies have shown defect-free β-Ga2O3 near a Al2O3 dielectric layer grown at 600°C [12]. In these samples, the Al2O3 layer was observed to be crystalline exactly along the interface and turning almost entirely amorphous stepping a few nanometers away from the β-Ga2O3 interface.
